channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘No Deal’ Brexit Finding Favor With British Conservatives
item.media:description: Anti-Brexit protesters in London this week.
item.description: A new poll of Conservative Party members shows that 57 percent prefer leaving the European Union without a deal, despite warnings of price increases and food shortages.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Spy or Not? American Who Loves Russia Ensnared in New Cold War
item.description: Paul N. Whelan, now in a Moscow prison, cut a curious figure. He traveled on Russian trains, collected tea glass holders and cultivated military contacts.
item.dc:creator: JULIAN E. BARNES and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: U.S. Renews China Travel Advisory, Warning of Arbitrary Detention
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo criticized exit bans during a visit to China in October. He again mentioned detained Americans at a meeting in Washington with a top Chinese foreign policy official, Yang Jiechi, left, in November.
item.description: The State Department said that possible “exit bans” could trap Americans in China.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Yellow Vest Leader Is Arrested in France Amid Crackdown
item.description: Eric Drouet’s arrest, his second over his role in the protests, signals that the government is following through on a pledge to get tough.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Archaeologists Find Pre-Columbian Temple of ‘Flayed Lord’ in Central Mexico
item.media:description: A stone carving depicting Xipe Tótec, a pre-Columbian god known as the Flayed Lord. Artifacts related to the deity were found in the central state of Puebla.
item.description: Mexico’s National Institute of Anthropology and History said archaeologists had found the first temple dedicated to an important fertility god, whose worshipers were said to wear the skin of sacrificial victims.
item.dc:creator: ALAN YUHAS

item.title: China’s Moon Landing: Lunar Rover Begins Its Exploration
item.media:description: The launch of the Chang’e 4 lunar probe in December. It has reached the far side of the moon, but some Chinese question whether the money was well spent.
item.description: Reaction in China to the landing was muted — a sign that the novelty of space missions has faded. But it also appeared to reflect political and economic anxieties.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Pope Cites ‘Crisis of Credibility’ in Message to U.S. Bishops on Sex Abuse
item.media:description: Pope Francis in St. Peter’s Square on Monday. He said the scandal had caused “division and dispersion” among the bishops.
item.description: The message comes as American bishops have been split in their attitudes about Francis, with a few openly criticizing the pope.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops

item.title: It Took On the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Now It’s in Pieces.
item.media:description: A test of the ocean-cleaning boom last year in Alameda, Calif. The group that created it said material fatigue and “local stress concentration” might have caused a fracture in the multimillion-dollar structure.
item.description: A giant boom was dispatched to tackle the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, but the forces of nature may have been too much for it. Its inventors plan to try again.
item.dc:creator: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Paraguay Dispatch: A Defiant Interview in a Jail Cell, Soon to Turn Into a Murder Scene
item.media:description: A mural of Pablo Escobar in Medellín, Colombia.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: In a prison interview, a drug lord called Paraguay “the land of impunity.” Hours later, it was hard not to interpret those words as a blood bath foretold.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Hackers Leak Details of German Lawmakers, Except Those on Far Right
item.media:description: Personal information about hundreds of German lawmakers was leaked by an anonymous Twitter account. None of those lawmakers were from the far-right party Alternative for Germany, or AfD.
item.description: Twitter has shut down an account that had been posting personal data for weeks. Only the Alternative for Germany party appeared to be unscathed.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: China Pours $218 Billion into the Economy as Growth Slows
item.media:description: A store in Shenzen. China has traditionally used its state-controlled banking system to flood the economy with money when growth slows.
item.description: The Chinese central bank’s move is intended to send a signal that Beijing is ready to stem a slowdown that has darkened the global outlook.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: At War: Afghan War Casualty Report: Dec. 28-Jan. 3
item.description: At least 75 pro-government forces and 14 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED

item.title: Philippine Police Kill Ex-Mayor Accused of Drug Crimes by Duterte
item.description: Talib Abo, who had a long history of conflict with President Rodrigo Duterte, and his brother were killed in separate police raids early Friday, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ

item.title: Congress, Stocks, China: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Representative Nancy Pelosi, center left, swore in Representative Deb Haaland, one of two Native American women in the new Congress.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Ringo Lam, Hong Kong Director of ‘City on Fire,’ Dies at 63
item.media:description: The director Ringo Lam receiving a Lifetime Achievement Award at the New York Asian Film Festival in New York in 2015.
item.media:credit: Brent N. Clarke/FilmMagic, via Getty Images
item.description: The veteran Hong Kong filmmaker whose 1987 hit movie famously influenced “Reservoir Dogs” died in his home of an unknown cause.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Russia, U.S. Congress, Brexit: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: The U.S. government refused to publicly discuss Paul Whelan’s status, but former C.I.A. officers said they did not think he was a spy.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN

item.title: At El Chapo’s Trial, a Son Betrays His Father, and the Cartel
item.media:description: Vicente Zambada Niebla, a former top lieutenant in the Sinaloa cartel, testified on Thursday in the drug trial of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the infamous crime lord known as El Chapo.
item.description: Vicente Zambada Niebla was groomed to run his father’s empire. Now he is a witness at El Chapo’s drug conspiracy trial.
item.dc:creator: ALAN FEUER

item.title: U.S. Accuses Iran of Using Space Launch as Cover for Missile Program
item.description: Responding to a warning from the secretary of state, Iran’s foreign minister said the U.S. was “in no position to lecture” about violating global deals after withdrawing from the 2015 nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Afghan Leaders Dispute Trump’s Claim That Soviets Invaded to Fight Terrorists
item.media:description: President Trump met with members of his cabinet on Wednesday, including Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan, right.
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani contested President Trump’s claim that the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan in 1979 to fight terrorists.
item.dc:creator: ALAN YUHAS

item.title: Congress, Espionage, China Economy: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Mexico Calls on U.S. to Investigate Use of Tear Gas at Border
item.media:description: Tear gas was used by border agents on Tuesday. The circumstances have been contested.
item.description: Mexico’s Foreign Ministry has asked for an investigation into two episodes at the border near San Diego, in which American border officers used tear gas to repel migrants.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and ALAN YUHAS

item.title: Letter 88: Reportage That Rises Into Art
item.description: A retrospective of Davd Goldblatt’s photographs from South Africa and Australia shows how art, like good journalism, connects one country to many others.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: U.S. Congress, Turkey, China: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Representative Nancy Pelosi being nominated to be speaker of the House inside the chamber.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Chinese Consumers’ Confidence Sags, Casting a Pall Over the Global Economy
item.media:description: An Apple store in Beijing. The company lowered its revenue forecast on Wednesday, citing disappointing iPhone sales in China.
item.description: Apple’s slumping iPhone sales in China are the latest sign that the country’s spenders are increasingly bothered by the economy, debt and other problems.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON, LI YUAN and RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Cathay Pacific Surprised by Its Own Offer: $16,000 Fare for $675
item.media:description: Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong’s flag carrier, unintentionally sold round-trip business-class flights to New York from Vietnam for less than the economy fare.
item.description: The low fares from Vietnam to North America were offered by mistake for several hours. But the airline said it would honor the bargain.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Offered Free Tickets for ‘Schindler’s List,’ Germany’s Far Right Sees a Provocation
item.media:description: Twenty-five years after its initial theatrical release, “Schindler’s List” is still a complex depiction of Nazi horrors. Its director, Steven Spielberg, hopes to provoke discussion by showing it again worldwide.
item.description: A German movie theater wanted to start a discussion about history and the Holocaust, but the AfD called the offer a “tasteless instrumentalization.”
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Saudi Arabia Seeks Death Penalty for 5 Suspects in Khashoggi Killing
item.description: Despite international scrutiny, the kingdom provided no new information on its agents’ roles in the death of the dissident Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Philippine Mayor Was Behind Congressman’s Killing, Police Say
item.description: A mayor ordered the Dec. 22 assassination of a lawmaker who was his political rival, and one of the men hired to carry it out has been arrested, the police said.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ

item.title: North Korea’s Envoy to Italy Disappears, Raising Suspicions of a Defection
item.media:description: The North Korean Embassy in Rome. Cho Seong-gil had been North Korea’s acting ambassador to Italy since October 2017.
item.description: Cho Seong-gil, whose term in Rome was nearing its end, has been in hiding since early November, according to a South Korean lawmaker.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH and SU-HYUN LEE

item.title: Government Shutdown, Moon Landing, Captain and Tennille: Your Thursday Briefing
item.media:description: After congressional leaders met with President Trump on Wednesday, Representative Nancy Pelosi said Democrats would propose legislation to end the shutdown.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: JILLIAN RAYFIELD

item.title: Artwork Taken From Africa, Returning to a Home Transformed
item.media:description: From left: Souleymane Bachir Diagne, Toyin Ojih Odutola and Cécile Fromont discuss the potential return of art to Africa at Ponty Bistro in Harlem.
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.description: A pivotal report calls for thousands of artworks to leave French museums and return to West Africa. An artist, a historian and a philosopher debate what should happen — and what these objects could mean to young Africans who have never seen them.
item.dc:creator: JASON FARAGO

item.title: Geoffrey Langlands, Lauded British Educator in Pakistan, Dies at 101
item.media:description: Geoffrey Langlands in 2012 on the grounds of Aitchison College in Lahore, Pakistan, where he spent 25 years as an educator. His pupils included at least two future prime ministers.
item.media:credit: Max Becherer for The New York Times
item.description: A British officer who stayed for six decades after his service ended, Mr. Langlands, known as “the Major,” taught at least two future prime ministers.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR and SANA ul-HAQ

item.title: Twisted Sister Clashes With Australian Politician Over Rock Anthem
item.media:description: Jay Jay French and Dee Snider of the American rock band Twisted Sister performing in Mexico City in 2016. They said they had not been informed that their song “We’re Not Gonna Take It” would be repurposed for a political advertisement in Australia.
item.description: Members of the American rock band objected to the use of their song “We’re Not Gonna Take It” for a political advertising campaign.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE TARABAY

item.title: Congress, Turkey, Apple: Your Thursday Briefing
item.media:description: In the last two to three years, not only have students and academics fled Turkey, but also entrepreneurs, businesspeople and thousands of wealthy individuals.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN

item.title: U.S. Ambassador Visits American Arrested in Russia on Spying Charge
item.media:description: Ambassador Jon M. Huntsman Jr. visited the detained American Paul N. Whelan on Wednesday.
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said he would demand the release of Paul N. Whelan, the Marine Corps veteran detained in Moscow, if the detention was “not appropriate.”
item.dc:creator: ALAN YUHAS

item.title: ‘New Chapter’ in Space Exploration as China Reaches Far Side of the Moon
item.media:description: The Chang’e-4 lunar probe being launched from Xichang, China, last month.
item.description: It was China’s second moon landing, and the first spacecraft to touch down on the side of the moon that always faces away from Earth.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS and ZOE MOU

item.title: These Migrants Rescued Greeks From the Sea. Their Reward: Citizenship.
item.media:description: Devastation in Mati, Greece, after wildfires in July. Dozens of people were rescued there after diving into the sea to escape the flames.
item.description: Greece awarded the men citizenship for their actions in July, when a fast-moving wildfire engulfed a seaside village near Athens.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS and ALAN YUHAS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Shutdown, Nancy Pelosi, Apple: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Saudi Arabia Denies Issuing American Weapons to Sudanese
item.media:description: Sudanese soldiers fighting for the Saudi-led coalition along the coastal highway near Hudaydah, Yemen.
item.description: Sudanese soldiers fighting for the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen had told The Times that they had been issued weapons they believed were American.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Jair Bolsonaro, on Day 1, Undermines Indigenous Brazilians’ Rights
item.media:description: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro (center) was sworn in on Tuesday.
item.description: As a candidate, President Jair Bolsonaro compared indigenous communities living in isolated areas to animals in zoos.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Trilobites: It’s Cold Outside, but Earth Is at Its Closest Approach to the Sun
item.media:description: Sunset over the Atlantic Ocean, viewed from the International Space Station in 2014.
item.description: Our planet’s elliptical orbit doesn’t affect winter or summer temperatures. But some astronomers wonder whether it’s a factor in why life survives.
item.dc:creator: SHANNON HALL

item.title: Where Doulas Calm Nerves and Bridge Cultures During Childbirth
item.media:description: The doula Oksana Kornieko, center, interpreted as the midwife Elisabeth Oskarsson suggested an epidural for Maria Hussein in Halmstad, Sweden. Ms. Hussein's husband, Abdulhanan Mohamed, is at left.
item.media:credit: Elisabeth Ubbe for The New York Times
item.description: In Sweden, midwives deliver babies. But doula culture interpreters act as bridges between midwives and immigrant women.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: Protests Break Out After 2 Women Enter Hindu Temple in India
item.description: The Sabarimala Temple in Kerala, India, until recently, barred women of childbearing age from entering. Two women went in for the first time, sparking protests both against the women and in support of women’s rights.

item.title: Spurning Erdogan’s Vision, Turks Leave in Droves, Draining Money and Talent

media:description.p: A commuter train in Istanbul passed an election poster for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan last June. Mr. Erdogan won re-election with greater powers, but the economy has faltered since then.

item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Driven by fear of persecution and economic mismanagement, the exodus threatens to reorder the society permanently and set Turkey back decades.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Freed From Forced Marriages, U.K. Women Stuck With the Bill
item.media:description: Britain’s foreign secretary, Jeremy Hunt, leaves the prime minister’s office at 10 Downing Street. The Foreign Office has been criticized for its policy of charging young women for their rescue from forced marriages.
item.description: Britain’s Foreign Office brought home 82 women from forced marriages over two years, then billed them as much as $1,000 for their return.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: China, Kerala, Moon Landing: Your Thursday Briefing
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping’s first major speech about Taiwan.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Uffizi Prods Germans to Return Painting Stolen in World War II
item.media:description: Eike Schmidt, director of the Uffizi Galleries in Florence, Italy, has hung a black-and-white copy of “Vase of Flowers,” by the Dutch painter Jan van Huysum with the word “stolen” in different languages.
item.media:credit: Uffizi press office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A German family has the artwork, and refuses to give it back. The Italian museum has mounted a publicity campaign in an effort to get German authorities to intervene.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
item.media:description: The director in Roma, near where he grew up. In the film he wanted to explore personal wounds, family wounds and wounds he shared with the country. “The presence of the city, in that sense, is fundamental.”
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE
